journey.description: The project started purely as an idea: finding a way to help rheumatoid arthritis patients stay connected with their doctors without needing constant in-person visits. The core problem identified was that patients experience daily flare-ups and condition changes that are impossible to fully explain during monthly appointments.

The next phase focused on hardware feasibility. At this stage, the full sensor set was not yet defined. Extensive research was conducted to identify which sensors could realistically track rheumatoid arthritis indicators. This included researching and selecting motion sensors (MPU), flex sensors for finger joints, PPG for heart rate monitoring, pressure sensors, and vibration motors for relief. The ESP32 was chosen as the central controller, and low-level programming was required to make all components work together reliably.

Significant effort went into sensor placement, wiring, and stability to ensure accurate readings from hand joints and fingers. A vibration-based relief system was embedded into the glove to activate during flare-ups, turning the device from a passive monitor into an active relief tool.

journey.title: Mobile Application & Accessibility Design
journey.description: A Flutter mobile application was developed for patients. A major focus here was accessibility: the system automatically detects and connects to the assigned glove when the patient logs in, removing the need for manual pairing. This was critical because users suffer from joint mobility limitations. The app allows patients to check vitals, monitor daily condition changes, and book doctor appointments directly.

Calibration logic was implemented for every sensor to ensure readings were meaningful per patient. This included joint movement calibration, finger flex calibration, and PPG calibration for heart rate accuracy. This phase was essential for transforming raw sensor data into medically useful information.

projects.longDescription:
RMTS was built as an end-to-end health monitoring system centered around a wearable smart glove. The glove integrates motion and biomedical sensors to track hand movement, stiffness, and condition progression related to rheumatoid arthritis. Data is transmitted via Bluetooth Low Energy to a Flutter mobile application, where patients can view their condition in real time.
A vibration-based relief system embedded inside the glove activates during detected flare-ups to help reduce discomfort.
On the clinical side, a dedicated web platform allows doctors to review patient history, monitor trends, manage appointments, and receive AI-generated medical reports based on collected sensor data.
The project was validated nationally after ranking 8th place at Technofest, competing against over 13,000 projects in the Health Technologies category.

Why generic AI systems fail in legal contexts

projects.challenge:
The core challenge was engineering both intelligence and usability at scale.

On the backend, over 1.5 million EU legal documents were statistically overpowering Finnish national statutes, causing incorrect prioritization in search results. On the frontend, most AI legal tools fail to offer interfaces suitable for professional legal work.

The challenge was to design a system that:

Retrieves the right law, not just the closest text

Guarantees traceable citations

Provides a dashboard lawyers can actually work with daily
projects.longDescription:
SnowLex was built to solve two deeply connected problems in modern legal technology:

- the unreliability of generic AI in legal reasoning, and

- the lack of usable, modern interfaces for AI-powered legal research.

While most LegalTech tools focus either on backend intelligence or basic chat interfaces, SnowLex was designed as a full-stack legal research system. The project includes not only a research-grade RAG pipeline, but also a fully custom Next.js web application, built from scratch to support real legal workflows.

The platform enables lawyers and researchers to interact with AI through a structured dashboard: managing chats, uploading legal documents, reviewing citations, and navigating sources with full transparency. Every UI decision was guided by legal usability principlesÔÇöclarity, traceability, and trust.

SnowLex treats law as structured knowledge, not just text. The system enforces citation grounding at every step, ensuring that AI responses are not only fast, but legally defensible.
